Well, it's a tiny patch of land in the north of Sri Lanka on the eastern coast.
It's about the size of Central Park.
It's really just a spit of land now and it's shrinking rapidly.
There's been intense fighting around there today.

Government forces have been trying to pierce Tamil Tiger defenses in order to reach some tens of thousands of civilians who are being held by the Tamil Tigers for months now serving as a buffer against government assaults.
There are reports of some of these civilians wading across a lagoon, essentially wading across the frontline to get to safety.
Have you confirmed that?
Yeah, well, that's pretty much the way a lot of people have escaped.
There were about 130,000 who escaped the same way shortly after April the 20th.

And as of this afternoon we have begun getting reports of thousands of people, once again, wading across the lagoon, which suggests that government forces have managed to get close enough to be able to give these people a chance to break out of the combat zone.
But, still, many left.
And you're saying that the civilians who are on the other side are being held by force by the Tamil Tigers.
We've had good indications of that for months now.
Civilians who have escaped have told us many, many stories of being forced back or shot at as they were escaping, with people being killed as they were trying to escape.
It's pretty clear that the - that at least for a very large proportion of the people in there, they were there against their will.
It makes sense.
These are families who were held there, people with small children.
There's no way that most of them would've chosen to have been there.
It was simply too dangerous.
Has any aid been getting to those civilians?
Very little - nothing close to adequate quantities.
People coming out - we can see signs of severe malnutrition - high levels amongst people who have managed to escape, as well as untreated battlefield wounds that people have been carrying.

We know from doctors inside the zone, with whom we've been in regular contact, that they have virtually no medical supplies, that there are thousands of people who are wounded and waiting for proper attention.
It's become a truly desperate situation for people inside the combat zone.
Speaking of doctors, we mentioned these attacks on a makeshift hospital.
Reports that the doctors have abandoned the hospital, there are patients still inside.

Fighting was so intense they were unable to even leave their bunkers.
We believe that there are many thousands of people who are badly wounded around the hospital premises.
We know anecdotally that lots of people were dying from relatively small wounds that would ordinarily have been treatable, except for the fact that there were not adequate medical supplies.
It's not really a hospital.
I mean, it's very makeshift.
It's (unintelligible) and spread over a sandy surface.

How do you see this immediate conflict resolving itself?
